 "cells": [

   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "2ed25ca2",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "\n",
    "# Alternative Solvers (e.g. Scipy, Petsc)\n",
    "Here we look at different ways of solving PDEs using external\n",
    "packages.\n",
    "Different linear algebra backends can be accessed by changing setting the\n",
    "`storage` parameter during construction of the discrete space. All\n",
    "discrete functions and operators/schemes based on this space will then\n",
    "use this backend. Available backends are `numpy,istl,petsc`. The default is\n",
    "`numpy` which uses simple data structures and linear solvers implemented in\n",
    "the `dune-fem` package - these backends were discussed\n",
    "[in the previously section](solversInternal_nb.ipynb).\n",
    "\n",
    "As discussed there, a degrees of freedom\n",
    "vector (dof vector) can be retrieved from a discrete function over the\n",
    "`numpy` space by using the `as_numpy` method. Similar attributes are available\n",
    "for the other storages, i.e., `as_istl,as_petsc`. These attributes are\n",
    "also available to retrieve the underlying matrix structures of linear\n",
    "operators. We will show now how to use this to use `scipy` or `petsc4py`\n",
    "to solve the (non) linear systems.\n",
    "\n",
    "We start with the same setup as used [in the previously section](solversInternal_nb.ipynb):"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "id": "9e9b85ac",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:04.089093Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:04.088776Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:05.933679Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:05.932571Z"
    },
    "lines_to_next_cell": 1
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "\n",
    "from dune.grid import structuredGrid as leafGridView\n",
    "from dune.fem.space import lagrange\n",
    "from dune.fem import integrate\n",
    "from ufl import TestFunction, TrialFunction, SpatialCoordinate, FacetNormal, \\\n",
    "                dx, ds, div, grad, dot, inner, exp, sin, conditional\n",
    "\n",
    "gridView = leafGridView([0, 0], [1, 1], [24, 24])\n",
    "space = lagrange(gridView, order=2)\n",
    "u_h = space.interpolate(0, name='u_h')\n",
    "\n",
    "x,u,v,n = ( SpatialCoordinate(space), TrialFunction(space), TestFunction(space), FacetNormal(space) )\n",
    "exact = 1/2*(x[0]**2+x[1]**2) - 1/3*(x[0]**3 - x[1]**3) + 1\n",
    "\n",
    "a  = ( inner(grad(u),grad(v)) + (1+u**2)*u*v ) * dx\n",
    "bf = (-div(grad(exact)) + (1+exact**2)*exact) * v * dx\n",
    "bg = dot(grad(exact),n)*v*ds\n",
    "\n",
    "# simple function to show the result of a simulation\n",
    "def printResult(method,error,info):\n",
    "    print(method,\"L^2, H^1 error:\",'{:0.5e}, {:0.5e}'.format(\n",
    "                 *[ np.sqrt(e) for e in integrate([error**2,inner(grad(error),grad(error))]) ]),\n",
    "          \"\\n\\t\",\"solver info=\",info,flush=True)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "7c19bf30",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We will use the `galerkin` operator from `dune.fem.operator` instead of the\n",
    "`scheme` used so far, since we do not need the `solve` method since we\n",
    "want to use external solvers in this section:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "id": "097b2782",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:05.935776Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:05.935480Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.018900Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.018078Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "from dune.fem.operator import galerkin\n",
    "from dune.ufl import DirichletBC\n",
    "operator = galerkin([a - (bf+bg), DirichletBC(space,exact,2)])"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "19c513ea",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Accessing underlying data structures\n",
    "\n",
    "The most important step is accessing the data structures setup on the C++\n",
    "side in Python. In this case we would like to use the underlying dof vector from\n",
    "a discrete function as numpy arrays and system matrices assembled by the\n",
    "schemes and operators as scipy sparse matrices.\n",
    "\n",
    "In the [introduction](dune-fempy_nb.ipynb) we already discussed the\n",
    "`as_numpy` attribute which allows access to the degrees of freedom as\n",
    "numpy array based on the `python buffer protocol`.\n",
    "So no data is copied and changes to the dofs made on the Python side are\n",
    "automatically carried over to the C++ side.\n",
    "\n",
    "We setup `u_h` to be zero but can initialize the dof vector with a random\n",
    "values directly changing `u_h` itself:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "id": "005f9a4b",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.021163Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.020939Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.344736Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.343873Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/jpeg": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 320x240 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "u_h.as_numpy[:] = np.random.rand(space.size)\n",
    "u_h.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "a2f93207",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    ".. tip:: changes to the numpy array `u_h.as_numpy` carries over to the discrete\n",
    "   function `u_h`, just remember to make changes using `vecu_h[:]` to change the actual\n",
    "   memory buffer.\n",
    "\n",
    "An instance of `dune.fem.operator` describing an operator `L`\n",
    "provides a method `linear` which returns an object that\n",
    "stores a sparse matrix structure. The object describes the operator\n",
    "linearized around zero.\n",
    "To linearize around a different value use the `jacobian` method on the\n",
    "`operator` that linearized\n",
    "the the operator `L` around a given grid function `ubar` and fills the\n",
    "linear operator structure passed in as second argument. It is also\n",
    "possible to pass ``assemble=False`` to the ``linear`` method to avoid an\n",
    "the linearization around zero to reduce computational cost:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "id": "32460c27",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.346864Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.346665Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.390145Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.389084Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "linOp = operator.linear()                  # linearized around 0\n",
    "linOp = operator.linear(assemble=False)    # empty (non valid) linear operator\n",
    "operator.jacobian(space.zero, linOp)       # linearized around zero"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "46fe59b8",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Here we linearize around zero. But that argument could be any grid\n",
    "function. A second version of this method will return an addition\n",
    "discrete function `rhs` which equals `-L[ubar]` such that `DL[ubar](u-ubar) - rhs` are the first\n",
    "terms in the Taylor expansion of the operator `L`:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 5,
   "id": "67d3b41f",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.392512Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.392265Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.400193Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.399025Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "rhs = u_h.copy()\n",
    "operator.jacobian(u_h, linOp, rhs)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "2b46093e",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "One can now easily access the underlying sparse matrix by again using\n",
    "`as_numpy` (and again the underlying data buffers are not copied):"
   ]
  },
  {

   "id": "b7e49361",
   "metadata": {

   "source": [
    "A = linOp.as_numpy\n",
    "print(type(A),flush=True)\n",
    "plt.spy(A, precision=1e-8, markersize=1)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "e7eaba5a",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Defining discrete function with given external dof vector\n",
    "\n",
    "As a last step we sometimes need to construct a discrete function based\n",
    "on a given dof vector. Here a simple example where we use a `numpy`\n",
    "random vector as dof vector for a discrete function:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 7,
   "id": "f88f5f5c",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.487742Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.487544Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.807638Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.806762Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [

     "data": {

      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "v_coeff = np.random.rand(space.size)\n",
    "vh = space.function(\"random\", dofVector=v_coeff)\n",
    "vh.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "14a7d8d7",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Again the dof vector is not copied so changing the `numpy` array will\n",
    "directly change the discrete function"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 8,
   "id": "90f2e1c9",
   "metadata": {

  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "31c57209",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Now we have all the ingredients to write a simple Newton solver to solve\n",
    "our non-linear time dependent PDE."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "69ed8fd0",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    ".. index::\n",
    "   pair: Solvers; Scipy\n",
    "\n",
    "## Using Scipy\n",
    "In our first example, we implement a simple Newton Krylov solver using a\n",
    "`cg` solver from Scipy.\n",
    "\n",
    ".. note::\n",
    "   As pointed out the system matrix is no longer\n",
    "   symmetric due to the handling of the Dirichlet constraints. For this\n",
    "   reason we need to provide an initial guess to the `cg` solver with the\n",
    "   degrees of freedom on the boundary set to be equal to the corresponding\n",
    "   degrees of freedom in the right hand side vector. For this we use the\n",
    "   `setConstraints` method on the solver."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 9,
   "id": "10a65c8c",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.976090Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:06.975868Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:44:39.225484Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:44:39.224479Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "iter 0 : 4.431052148382562\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "iter 1 : 0.04276612643235494\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "iter 2 : 0.002883781339264266\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "iter 3 : 2.2434900427670995e-05\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "iter 4 : 1.4130851244438762e-09\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Scipy-1 L^2, H^1 error: 1.17626e-06, 1.83002e-04 \n",
      "\t solver info= {'iterations': 4, 'linear_iterations': 856}\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/jpeg": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 320x240 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from scipy.sparse.linalg import cg\n",
    "class Scheme1:\n",
    "    def __init__(self, op):\n",
    "        self.model = op.model\n",
    "        self.jacobian = op.linear()\n",
    "        self.op = op\n",
    "        self.linIter = 0\n",
    "\n",
    "    def callback(self,x):\n",
    "        self.linIter += 1\n",
    "\n",
    "    def solve(self, target):\n",
    "        # create a copy of target for the residual\n",
    "        res = target.copy(name=\"residual\")\n",
    "        initialGuess = target.copy(name=\"initial-guess\")\n",
    "\n",
    "        # extract numpy vectors from target and res\n",
    "        sol_coeff = target.as_numpy\n",
    "        res_coeff = res.as_numpy\n",
    "        x0 = initialGuess.as_numpy\n",
    "\n",
    "        n = 0\n",
    "        while True:\n",
    "            self.op(target, res)\n",
    "            absF = np.sqrt( np.dot(res_coeff,res_coeff) )\n",
    "            print(f\"iter {n} : {absF}\",flush=True)\n",
    "            if absF < 1e-6:\n",
    "                break\n",
    "            self.op.jacobian(target,self.jacobian)\n",
    "            self.op.setConstraints(res,initialGuess)\n",
    "            dh_coeff = cg(self.jacobian.as_numpy, res_coeff, x0,\n",
    "                          callback=self.callback )\n",
    "            sol_coeff -= dh_coeff[0]\n",
    "            n += 1\n",
    "        return {\"iterations\":n, \"linear_iterations\":self.linIter}\n",
    "\n",
    "scheme1_cls = Scheme1(operator)\n",
    "u_h.interpolate(2)\n",
    "info = scheme1_cls.solve(target=u_h)\n",
    "printResult(\"Scipy-1\",u_h-exact,info)\n",
    "u_h.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "df75a245",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We can also use a non linear solver from the Scipy package - together\n",
    "for example with an incomplete LU factorization for the Jacobian.\n",
    "\n",
    ".. note::\n",
    "   since we are using a LU type method here (i.e. a direct solver) we do\n",
    "   not need to worry about the constraints as with the `cg` method\n",
    "   previously."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 10,
   "id": "19c487ec",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:44:39.227506Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:44:39.227199Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.707854Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.707069Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Newton residual: 0.001828755764603685\n",
      "Newton residual: 8.31304825565234e-06\n",
      "Newton residual: 5.036723327866297e-10\n",
      "Newton residual: 1.7494444054154788e-17\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Scipy-2 L^2, H^1 error: 1.17626e-06, 1.83002e-04 \n",
      "\t solver info= {'iterations': 4, 'linear_iterations': 16}\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/jpeg": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 320x240 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from scipy.optimize import newton_krylov\n",
    "from scipy.sparse.linalg import LinearOperator,spilu\n",
    "\n",
    "class Scheme2:\n",
    "    def __init__(self, op):\n",
    "        self.op = op\n",
    "        self.model = op.model\n",
    "        self.linIter = 0\n",
    "\n",
    "    def linCallback(self,x):\n",
    "        self.linIter += 1\n",
    "    def linSolver(self,*args,**kwargs):\n",
    "        return cg(*args,**kwargs,callback=self.linCallback)\n",
    "\n",
    "    # non linear function\n",
    "    def f(self, x_coeff):\n",
    "        # the following converts a given numpy array\n",
    "        # into a discrete function over the given space\n",
    "        x = self.op.domainSpace.function(\"tmp\", dofVector=x_coeff)\n",
    "        self.op(x, self.res)\n",
    "        return self.res.as_numpy\n",
    "    def callback(self,x,fx):\n",
    "        print(\"Newton residual:\",fx.dot(fx))\n",
    "\n",
    "    # class for the derivative DS of S\n",
    "    class Df(LinearOperator):\n",
    "        def __init__(self, op, x_coeff):\n",
    "            self.op = op\n",
    "            self.shape = (x_coeff.shape[0], x_coeff.shape[0])\n",
    "            self.dtype = x_coeff.dtype\n",
    "            x = self.op.domainSpace.function(\"tmp\", dofVector=x_coeff)\n",
    "            self.jacobian = self.op.linear()\n",
    "            self.n = -1\n",
    "            self.update(x_coeff,None)\n",
    "        # reassemble the matrix DF(u) given a DoF vector for u\n",
    "        def update(self, x_coeff, f):\n",
    "            x = self.op.domainSpace.function(\"tmp\", dofVector=x_coeff)\n",
    "            self.op.jacobian(x, self.jacobian)\n",
    "            self.invJac = spilu(self.jacobian.as_numpy.tocsc())\n",
    "            self.n += 1\n",
    "        # compute DS(u)^{-1}x for a given DoF vector x\n",
    "        def _matvec(self, x_coeff):\n",
    "            return self.invJac.solve(x_coeff)\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "    def solve(self, target):\n",
    "        self.res = target.copy(name=\"residual\")\n",
    "        sol_coeff = target.as_numpy\n",
    "        M = self.Df(self.op,sol_coeff)\n",
    "        # call the newton krylov solver from scipy\n",
    "        sol_coeff[:] = newton_krylov(self.f, sol_coeff,\n",
    "                    f_tol=1e-6, callback=self.callback,\n",
    "                    method=self.linSolver, inner_M=M)\n",
    "        return {\"iterations\":M.n, \"linear_iterations\":self.linIter}\n",
    "\n",
    "scheme2_cls = Scheme2(operator)\n",
    "u_h.interpolate(2)\n",
    "info = scheme2_cls.solve(target=u_h)\n",
    "printResult(\"Scipy-2\",u_h-exact,info)\n",
    "u_h.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "e80959ba",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    ".. index::\n",
    "   pair: Solvers; Umfpack (scikit)\n",
    "\n",
    "## Using scikit-umfpack\n",
    "While `umfpack` can be used as a direct [internal solver](solversInternal_nb.ipynb)\n",
    "a more fine grained usage is sometimes available through the Python\n",
    "binding for `umfpack` available through the `scikit` package.\n",
    "which needs to be installed for the following to run:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 11,
   "id": "733a80f1",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.710048Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.709828Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.713364Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.712577Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "try:\n",
    "    import scikits.umfpack as um\n",
    "except ModuleNotFoundError:\n",
    "    print(\"can not import scikits.umfpacl \")\n",
    "    um = None"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "8484403e",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We will demonstrate the usage by solving our non-linear problem with a\n",
    "hand written Newton method assuming that the symbolic\n",
    "decomposition of the system matrix can be reused in each step:\n",
    "\n",
    "if um:\n",
    "    class Scheme3:\n",
    "        def __init__(self, op):\n",
    "            self.model = op.model\n",
    "            self.jacobian = op.linear()\n",
    "            self.op = op\n",
    "            self.umfpack = um.UmfpackContext() # Use default 'di' family of UMFPACK routines.\n",
    "            self.umfpack.symbolic( self.jacobian.as_numpy )\n",
    "\n",
    "        def solve(self, target):\n",
    "            # create a copy of target for the residual\n",
    "            res = target.copy(name=\"residual\")\n",
    "\n",
    "            # extract numpy vectors from target and res\n",
    "            sol_coeff = target.as_numpy\n",
    "            res_coeff = res.as_numpy\n",
    "\n",
    "            n = 0\n",
    "            while True:\n",
    "                self.op(target, res)\n",
    "                absF = np.sqrt( np.dot(res_coeff,res_coeff) )\n",
    "                print(f\"iter {n} : {absF}\",flush=True)\n",
    "                if absF < 1e-6:\n",
    "                    break\n",
    "                self.op.jacobian(target,self.jacobian)\n",
    "                A = self.jacobian.as_numpy[:]\n",
    "                self.umfpack.numeric( A )\n",
    "                sol_coeff -= self.umfpack( um.UMFPACK_A, A, res_coeff, autoTranspose = True )\n",
    "                n += 1\n",
    "            return {\"iterations\":n, \"linear_iterations\":-1}\n",
    "\n",
    "    scheme1_cls = Scheme3(operator)\n",
    "    u_h.interpolate(2)\n",
    "    info = scheme1_cls.solve(target=u_h)\n",
    "    printResult(\"scikit-umfpack\",u_h-exact,info)\n",
    "    u_h.plot()"
   ]
  },

    ".. index::\n",
    "   pair: Solvers; Petsc4Py\n",
    "\n",
    "## Using PETSc4Py\n",
    "The following requires that a PETSc installation was found during the\n",
    "configuration of ``dune``. Furthermore the Python package ``petsc4py`\n",
    "is required:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 12,
   "id": "583a9213",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.715171Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.714976Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.721313Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.720383Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "petsc4py module not found -- skipping example\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "from dune.common.checkconfiguration import assertCMakeHave, ConfigurationError\n",
    "try:\n",
    "    assertCMakeHave(\"HAVE_PETSC\")\n",
    "    petsc = True\n",
    "except ConfigurationError:\n",
    "    print(\"Dune not configured with petsc - skipping example\")\n",
    "    petsc = False\n",
    "try:\n",
    "    import sys\n",
    "    import petsc4py\n",
    "    petsc4py.init(sys.argv)\n",
    "    from petsc4py import PETSc\n",
    "except ModuleNotFoundError:\n",
    "    print(\"petsc4py module not found -- skipping example\")\n",
    "    petsc4py = None"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "4da7e567",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "To use `petsc4py` we need to which to a storage based on the PETSc package\n",
    "using the ``storage`` argument to the space constructor.\n",
    "\n",
    "Implementing a Newton Krylov solver using the binding provided by\n",
    "`petsc4py` is now straightforward - we again use incomplete LU as\n",
    "preconditioner:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 13,
   "id": "11a1f46f",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.723003Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.722805Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.729518Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.728729Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "if petsc4py is not None and petsc:\n",
    "    petsc_options = PETSc.Options()\n",
    "    spacePetsc = lagrange(gridView, order=2, storage='petsc')\n",
    "    u_h = spacePetsc.interpolate(2, name='u_h')  # start with solution at top boundary\n",
    "    opPetsc = galerkin([a==bf+bg,DirichletBC(spacePetsc,exact,2)],\n",
    "                       domainSpace=spacePetsc,rangeSpace=spacePetsc)\n",
    "\n",
    "    class Scheme4:\n",
    "        def __init__(self, op):\n",
    "            self.op = op\n",
    "            self.jacobian = op.linear()\n",
    "            self.ksp = PETSc.KSP()\n",
    "            self.ksp.create(PETSc.COMM_WORLD)\n",
    "            # use conjugate gradients method\n",
    "            self.ksp.setType(\"cg\")\n",
    "            # use sor preconditioner\n",
    "            # self.ksp.getPC().setType(\"sor\")\n",
    "            # or ILU(1)\n",
    "            self.ksp.getPC().setType(\"ilu\")\n",
    "            petsc_options['pc_factor_levels'] = 1\n",
    "            self.ksp.setOperators(self.jacobian.as_petsc)\n",
    "            self.ksp.setInitialGuessNonzero(True)\n",
    "            self.ksp.setFromOptions()\n",
    "        def solve(self, target):\n",
    "            res = target.copy(name=\"residual\")\n",
    "            dh = target.copy(name=\"direction\")\n",
    "            sol_coeff = target.as_petsc\n",
    "            dh_coeff = dh.as_petsc\n",
    "            res_coeff = res.as_petsc\n",
    "            n = 0\n",
    "            numIter = 0\n",
    "            while True:\n",
    "                self.op(target, res)\n",
    "                absF = np.sqrt( np.dot(res_coeff,res_coeff) )\n",
    "                if absF < 1e-6:\n",
    "                    break\n",
    "                dh.clear()\n",
    "                self.op.jacobian(target,self.jacobian)\n",
    "                self.op.setConstraints(res,dh) # petsc does not seem to need this...\n",
    "                self.ksp.setUp()\n",
    "                self.ksp.solve(res_coeff, dh_coeff)\n",
    "                numIter += self.ksp.getIterationNumber()\n",
    "                sol_coeff -= dh_coeff\n",
    "                n += 1\n",
    "            return {\"iterations\":n, \"linear_iterations\":numIter}\n",
    "\n",
    "    u_h.interpolate(2)\n",
    "    scheme3_cls = Scheme4(opPetsc)\n",
    "    info = scheme3_cls.solve(target=u_h)\n",
    "    printResult(\"PETSc4py 1\",u_h-exact,info)\n",
    "    u_h.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "41bf2316",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Here is another example now using the petsc4py bindings for the non\n",
    "linear KSP solvers from PETSc. This time we use a algebraic multigrid\n",
    "preconditioner:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 14,
   "id": "0a4ab25e",
   "metadata": {
    "execution": {
     "iopub.execute_input": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.731371Z",
     "iopub.status.busy": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.731203Z",
     "iopub.status.idle": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.737253Z",
     "shell.execute_reply": "2025-11-30T13:45:11.736505Z"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "if petsc4py is not None and petsc is not None:\n",
    "    class Scheme5:\n",
    "        def __init__(self, op):\n",
    "            self.op = op\n",
    "            self.res = op.rangeSpace.interpolate(0,name=\"residual\")\n",
    "            self.jacobian = op.linear()\n",
    "            self.snes = PETSc.SNES().create()\n",
    "            self.snes.setFunction(self.f, self.res.as_petsc.duplicate())\n",
    "            self.snes.setUseMF(False)\n",
    "            self.snes.setJacobian(self.Df, self.jacobian.as_petsc, self.jacobian.as_petsc)\n",
    "            self.snes.setTolerances(atol=1e-6)\n",
    "            self.snes.getKSP().setType(\"cg\")\n",
    "            self.snes.getKSP().getPC().setType(\"hypre\")\n",
    "            petsc_options['pc_hypre_type'] = 'boomeramg'\n",
    "            self.snes.setFromOptions()\n",
    "\n",
    "        def f(self, snes, x, f):\n",
    "            # setup discrete function using the provide petsc vectors\n",
    "            inDF = self.op.domainSpace.function(\"tmp\",dofVector=x)\n",
    "            outDF = self.op.rangeSpace.function(\"tmp\",dofVector=f)\n",
    "            self.op(inDF,outDF)\n",
    "\n",
    "        def Df(self, snes, x, m, b):\n",
    "            inDF = self.op.domainSpace.function(\"tmp\",dofVector=x)\n",
    "            self.op.jacobian(inDF, self.jacobian)\n",
    "            return PETSc.Mat.Structure.SAME_NONZERO_PATTERN\n",
    "\n",
    "        def solve(self, target):\n",
    "            sol_coeff = target.as_petsc\n",
    "            self.res.clear()\n",
    "            self.snes.solve(self.res.as_petsc, sol_coeff)\n",
    "            return {\"iterations\":self.snes.getIterationNumber(),\n",
    "                    \"linear_iterations\":self.snes.getLinearSolveIterations()}\n",
    "\n",
    "    scheme4_cls = Scheme5(opPetsc)\n",
    "    u_h.interpolate(2)\n",
    "    info = scheme4_cls.solve(target=u_h)\n",
    "    printResult(\"PETSc4py 2\",u_h-exact,info)\n",
    "    u_h.plot()"
   ]
  }
